learningOutcomes.fi:
This course aims to address directly one of the main objectives of the EIT AMIS Master's Programme by preparing graduates to plan and prepare for their professional career as entrepreneurially minded scientists and researchers, while developing and leveraging their complementary competences. The course draws heavily on a learning-by-doing pedagogical approach, which is reflected on how the course is designed and how students are assessed. 
Under completion of the course the student will be able to develop the following knowledge and skills:
  • Ability to work collaboratively in using and analyzing advanced materials for a given functional application 
  • Develop knowledge and expertise from the application of new research methods, processes and techniques in using and analyzing advanced materials for a given functional application
  • Develop knowledge and expertise in developing business models from the commercialization process of new technologies within a University
  • Ability to identify immediate consequences of plans and decisions in developing business solutions from technological innovations
  • Develop expertise and capabilities in managing resources needed to commercialize new technologies
  • Develop knowledge and expertise in understanding the boundary conditions and constrains of the commercialization process within existing companies
  • Develop knowledge on the legal requirement in patenting intellectual property
  • Develop experience in liaising with the commercialization support services of various academic institutions

content.fi: The students will be allocated in small, cross-country, multidisciplinary teams and will primarily focus on the scientific development of the project. Each project will be supervised by an academic supervisor, and it will result in a scientific paper, while the process of developing the paper will be documented in a Wiki platform.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Understand the scientific principles and the ecological consequences of material flows
Understand policy and technology drivers of material circulation
Understand the consequences of material selection and design for the circulation and recovery of materials
Are able to prioritize activities and develop solutions for circular economy and the bioeconomy
learningOutcomes.sv: Understand the scientific principles and the ecological consequences of material flowsUnderstand policy and technology drivers of material circulationUnderstand the consequences of material selection and design for the circulation and recovery of materialsAre able to prioritize activities and develop solutions for circular economy and the bioeconomy
learningOutcomes.en: Understand the scientific principles and the ecological consequences of material flowsUnderstand policy and technology drivers of material circulationUnderstand the consequences of material selection and design for the circulation and recovery of materialsAre able to prioritize activities and develop solutions for circular economy and the bioeconomy

content.fi:
The use of materials by humans is having a profound and transformative effect upon the biosphere and yet is an integral part of the global economy and society. The course aims to consider how we might rethink our use of materials in the context of sustainable development.
We will explore the nexus between materials and sustainability, adopting a systems thinking approach to materials cycles. We will look at how the use of material and the choices we make in their selection, and the design of materials and products, affect sustainability. We will look at how we can improve resource efficiency and will explore the limits to this. We will look at material flows and the stakeholders involved in often highly complex value chains.

additionalInformation.fi:
Teaching Language: English Teaching Period: 2024-2025 Spring III  2025-2026 Spring III Registration: Maximum 60 students. The course is mandatory for students of the Creative Sustainability programme. If fewer than 60 places are taken by students of Creative Sustainability, the remaining places will be allocated to students from other programs, with those taking Creative Sustainability as a minor prioritized. These students will be selected on the basis of their field of study to ensure that we are able to create multidisciplinary teams for group working.
A course implementation may be cancelled if the number of students enrolled to the course implementation does not meet the required minimum of five students. In the case of cancelled course implementations, the students enrolled to them must be provided with an alternative way of completing the course or be advised to take some other applicable course.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student
1. masters the basic principles of  nanochemistry, nanoengineering and green nanotechnology.
2. has an overview of state-of-the-art synthesis techniques of advanced nanomaterials and new-material design of the desired functions
3. is able to analyze physical property relations in functional materials
4. is able to apply methods/approaches/ideas from scientific papers to own study topics related to materials chemistry

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student will be able to
1. interpret MS, IR and NMR spectra
2. solve structures of organic molecules based on MS, IR and NMR spectra
3. describe the functional principles of the MS, IR and NMR spectrometers
learningOutcomes.sv: After the course the student will be able to 1. interpret MS, IR and NMR spectra 2. solve structures of organic molecules based on MS, IR and NMR spectra 3. describe the functional principles of the MS, IR and NMR spectrometers
learningOutcomes.en: After the course the student will be able to 1. interpret MS, IR and NMR spectra 2. solve structures of organic molecules based on MS, IR and NMR spectra 3. describe the functional principles of the MS, IR and NMR spectrometers

content.fi:
The objective is to learn how to use mass spectrometry (MS), infrared spectroscopy (IR) and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) in the structural determination and identification of organic compounds. After the course, the student should know:
  • How to determine molecular weight and molecular formula from the mass spectral data
  • How to calculate the Double Bond Equivalent (DBE) based on the molecular formula
  • How to identify molecular functional groups from the infrared spectra
  • How 1H NMR signal integrals are related to a molecular structure
  • How 1H and 13C NMR chemical shifts are related to a molecular structure
  • How 1H,1H NMR coupling constants are related to a molecular structure
  • How equivalence, symmetry and chirality effect on the NMR spectra
  • How to interpret simple 2D NMR spectra

  • How to identify molecular functional groups from the infrared spectra

  • How 1H and 13C NMR chemical shifts are related to a molecular structure
  • How 1H,1H NMR coupling constants are related to a molecular structure

  • How to interpret simple 2D NMR spectra

assesmentMethods.fi:
Lectures and exercises. Final exam. 
Evaluation is based on the final exam, which contains three structure determination problems. Please note that the answers to the exam questions cannot be found directly in the textbooks or in the course handout. Therefore, it is important to practise structure determination by solving exercises at home.

workload.fi: 5 cr; 5 cr x 27 h/cr = 135 h Lectures, workshops, and examination: 50 h Project work: 85 h
workload.sv: 5 cr; 5 cr x 27 h/cr = 135 h Lectures, workshops, and examination: 50 h Project work: 85 h
workload.en: 5 cr; 5 cr x 27 h/cr = 135 h Lectures, workshops, and examination: 50 h Project work: 85 h

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: B.Sc. degreeRecommended prerequisites: Basic knowledge of process industry in the pulp and paper / forest biorefineries area.
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: B.Sc. degreeRecommended prerequisites: Basic knowledge of process industry in the pulp and paper / forest biorefineries area.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: B.Sc. degreeRecommended prerequisites: Basic knowledge of process industry in the pulp and paper / forest biorefineries area.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course, the students
  • can summarise the activities included in the systematic planning, implementation, and management of a biomass-based process industry investment project.
  • can describe engineer's work in a consultancy company.
  • have experience in project work in teams, working with real-life tools for project planning, as well as on report writing and giving oral presentations.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course, the students
  • can summarise the activities included in the systematic planning, implementation, and management of a biomass-based process industry investment project.
  • can describe engineer's work in a consultancy company.
  • have experience in project work in teams, working with real-life tools for project planning, as well as on report writing and giving oral presentations.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course, the students
  • can summarise the activities included in the systematic planning, implementation, and management of a biomass-based process industry investment project.
  • can describe engineer's work in a consultancy company.
  • have experience in project work in teams, working with real-life tools for project planning, as well as on report writing and giving oral presentations.

content.fi: The course provides an overview of an investment project and all the activities included during the entire lifecycle of a project (i.e. from early studies to startup of the plant). These activities include, for instance, process engineering, project implementation planning, implementation methods, contract-, scope-, resource-, time-, cost- and risk management and engineering tools. The course includes a practical process design oriented exercise using a real-life project case. A part of the lectures, as well as the practical exercise, is arranged in a consultancy company. The exercise includes an oral presentation on the results.

The course includes a practical process design oriented exercise using a real-life project case. A part of the lectures, as well as the practical exercise, is arranged in a consultancy company. The exercise includes an oral presentation on the results.
content.en: The course provides an overview of an investment project and all the activities included during the entire lifecycle of a project (i.e. from early studies to startup of the plant). These activities include, for instance, process engineering, project implementation planning, implementation methods, contract-, scope-, resource-, time-, cost- and risk management and engineering tools. The course includes a practical process design oriented exercise using a real-life project case. A part of the lectures, as well as the practical exercise, is arranged in a consultancy company. The exercise includes an oral presentation on the results.

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: - CHEM-C2430 Polymeeriteknologian perusteet OR - CHEM-C3420 Basics of polymer technology OR - CHEM-E2100 'Polymer Synthesis' OR - CHEM-E2145 'Polymer Reaction Engineering' OR - corresponding knowledgeRecommended prerequisites:
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: - CHEM-C2430 Polymeeriteknologian perusteet OR - CHEM-C3420 Basics of polymer technology OR - CHEM-E2100 'Polymer Synthesis' OR - CHEM-E2145 'Polymer Reaction Engineering' OR - corresponding knowledgeRecommended prerequisites:
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: - CHEM-C2430 Polymeeriteknologian perusteet OR - CHEM-C3420 Basics of polymer technology OR - CHEM-E2100 'Polymer Synthesis' OR - CHEM-E2145 'Polymer Reaction Engineering' OR - corresponding knowledgeRecommended prerequisites:

learningOutcomes.fi:
After completing the course, the student:
  • is able to recall and apply basics aspects of polymer physics (thermodynamical and mechanical).
  • can correlate how the chemistry, structure, and hierarchy of polymers affect their material properties (e.g. viscoelasticity, toughness, and processability).
  • is familiar with the basics of the most important and common polymer characterization and analysis methods (e.g. molecular weight determination and material properties).
  • can outline the basic theories and phenomena in the rheology and viscoelastic properties of polymers.
  • can discuss the basic aspects of the stability and degradation of polymers.
  • is able to analyse and calculate the above-mentioned phenomena.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After completing the course, the student:
  • is able to recall and apply basics aspects of polymer physics (thermodynamical and mechanical).
  • can correlate how the chemistry, structure, and hierarchy of polymers affect their material properties (e.g. viscoelasticity, toughness, and processability).
  • is familiar with the basics of the most important and common polymer characterization and analysis methods (e.g. molecular weight determination and material properties).
  • can outline the basic theories and phenomena in the rheology and viscoelastic properties of polymers.
  • can discuss the basic aspects of the stability and degradation of polymers.
  • is able to analyse and calculate the above-mentioned phenomena.
learningOutcomes.en:
After completing the course, the student:
  • is able to recall and apply basics aspects of polymer physics (thermodynamical and mechanical).
  • can correlate how the chemistry, structure, and hierarchy of polymers affect their material properties (e.g. viscoelasticity, toughness, and processability).
  • is familiar with the basics of the most important and common polymer characterization and analysis methods (e.g. molecular weight determination and material properties).
  • can outline the basic theories and phenomena in the rheology and viscoelastic properties of polymers.
  • can discuss the basic aspects of the stability and degradation of polymers.
  • is able to analyse and calculate the above-mentioned phenomena.

content.fi: Theoretical aspects related to polymer chains, polymer analysis, physics, and rheology. How the structure and molecular weight of polymers affect thermal, mechanical, and viscoelastic properties. Structure hierarchy in polymers. Basics of stability and degradation of polymers. Calculation of polymer properties.
content.sv: Theoretical aspects related to polymer chains, polymer analysis, physics, and rheology. How the structure and molecular weight of polymers affect thermal, mechanical, and viscoelastic properties. Structure hierarchy in polymers. Basics of stability and degradation of polymers. Calculation of polymer properties.
content.en: Theoretical aspects related to polymer chains, polymer analysis, physics, and rheology. How the structure and molecular weight of polymers affect thermal, mechanical, and viscoelastic properties. Structure hierarchy in polymers. Basics of stability and degradation of polymers. Calculation of polymer properties.

additionalInformation.fi:
Teaching Language: English Teaching Period: 2024-2025 Autumn II 2025-2026 Autumn II Registration: Max 100 students prioritized in the following order: 
  1. All students in the majors Fibre and polymer engineering and 'Bioproducts Engineering are selected if enrolled in time.
  2. Students in majors Chemical and process engineering, Functional Materials and Chemistry and Materials Science.
  3. Students in major Biosystems and Biomaterials Engineering and minor Textile Chemistry.
  4. Students in the master's programme in Chemical, Biochemical, and Materials Engineering majors Chemistry, Biomass Refining, and Biotechnology.
  5. Students from other programs or departments, if there is availability.
A course implementation may be cancelled if the number of students enrolled to the course implementation does not meet the required minimum of five students. In the case of cancelled course implementations, the students enrolled to them must be provided with an alternative way of completing the course or be advised to take some other applicable course.

  1. All students in the majors Fibre and polymer engineering and 'Bioproducts Engineering are selected if enrolled in time.
  2. Students in majors Chemical and process engineering, Functional Materials and Chemistry and Materials Science.
  3. Students in major Biosystems and Biomaterials Engineering and minor Textile Chemistry.
  4. Students in the master's programme in Chemical, Biochemical, and Materials Engineering majors Chemistry, Biomass Refining, and Biotechnology.
  5. All doctoral students at the School of Chemical Engineering.
  6. Students from other programs or departments, if there is availability.
A course implementation may be cancelled if the number of students enrolled to the course implementation does not meet the required minimum of five students. In the case of cancelled course implementations, the students enrolled to them must be provided with an alternative way of completing the course or be advised to take some other applicable course.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Compulsory - CHEM-C2430 'Polymeeriteknologian perusteet' or CHEM-C3420 'Basics of polymer technology' or corresponding knowledge
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: Compulsory - CHEM-C2430 'Polymeeriteknologian perusteet' or CHEM-C3420 'Basics of polymer technology' or corresponding knowledge
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Compulsory - CHEM-C2430 'Polymeeriteknologian perusteet' or CHEM-C3420 'Basics of polymer technology' or corresponding knowledge

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student is able to:
  • outline the most common polymerization mechanisms and how they affect polymerization reactions.
  • describe production technologies of the most common polymers and present special features of the reactor types.
  • describe and discuss how the safety and stability of polymer reactors can be affected and is able to conduct stability analysis in research and development of polymer processes.
  • reflect how viscosity affects polymerization processes and can design mixing and heat transfer of polymerization reactors.
  • can scale up/down mixing of polymerizations.
  • explain the use of reactor calorimeter in polymerizations reactors.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course the student is able to:
  • outline the most common polymerization mechanisms and how they affect polymerization reactions.
  • describe production technologies of the most common polymers and present special features of the reactor types.
  • describe and discuss how the safety and stability of polymer reactors can be affected and is able to conduct stability analysis in research and development of polymer processes.
  • reflect how viscosity affects polymerization processes and can design mixing and heat transfer of polymerization reactors.
  • can scale up/down mixing of polymerizations.
  • explain the use of reactor calorimeter in polymerizations reactors.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student is able to:
  • outline the most common polymerization mechanisms and how they affect polymerization reactions.
  • describe production technologies of the most common polymers and present special features of the reactor types.
  • describe and discuss how the safety and stability of polymer reactors can be affected and is able to conduct stability analysis in research and development of polymer processes.
  • reflect how viscosity affects polymerization processes and can design mixing and heat transfer of polymerization reactors.
  • can scale up/down mixing of polymerizations.
  • explain the use of reactor calorimeter in polymerizations reactors.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course, the student:
- is able to analyze process dynamics derived from physics-based modelling and experimental data
- understands basic process control approaches with a single controlled variable
- understands process dynamics and control also in the Laplace domain
- has knowledge on common instrumentation in the process industries
- understands the stability in both time and in the Laplace domain
- understands how to compensate disturbances
- understands how to implement feedforward, cascade and ratio control
learningOutcomes.sv: After the course, the student:- is able to analyze process dynamics derived from physics-based modelling and experimental data- understands basic process control approaches with a single controlled variable- understands process dynamics and control also in the Laplace domain- has knowledge on common instrumentation in the process industries- understands the stability in both time and in the Laplace domain- understands how to compensate disturbances- understands how to implement feedforward, cascade and ratio control
learningOutcomes.en: After the course, the student:- is able to analyze process dynamics derived from physics-based modelling and experimental data- understands basic process control approaches with a single controlled variable- understands process dynamics and control also in the Laplace domain- has knowledge on common instrumentation in the process industries- understands the stability in both time and in the Laplace domain- understands how to compensate disturbances- understands how to implement feedforward, cascade and ratio control

content.fi: - Process automation and information systems, their basic functions and information management- Measurement techniques in the process industries, instrumentation standards, data acquisition, and process flow diagrams- Modelling of process dynamics, Laplace transformation and transfer functions- PID control and tuning- Stability analysis in both time and in the Laplace domain- The compensation of disturbances- Feedforward, cascade and ratio control
content.sv: - Process automation and information systems, their basic functions and information management- Measurement techniques in the process industries, instrumentation standards, data acquisition, and process flow diagrams- Modelling of process dynamics, Laplace transformation and transfer functions- PID control and tuning- Stability analysis in both time and in the Laplace domain- The compensation of disturbances- Feedforward, cascade and ratio control

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student
*Understands the process dynamics and nonlinearities of typical chemical processes and coupling between physical phenomena
*Can model chemical processes and carry out model based analysis
*Can solve mechanistic process models using appropriate numerical techniques
learningOutcomes.sv: After the course the student *Understands the process dynamics and nonlinearities of typical chemical processes and coupling between physical phenomena *Can model chemical processes and carry out model based analysis *Can solve mechanistic process models using appropriate numerical techniques
learningOutcomes.en: After the course the student *Understands the process dynamics and nonlinearities of typical chemical processes and coupling between physical phenomena *Can model chemical processes and carry out model based analysis *Can solve mechanistic process models using appropriate numerical techniques

content.fi: Dynamical process modeling with material and energy balances Effect of rate models (mass and heat transfer, reaction rates) on modeling Specific topics in mass transfer: multicomponent mass transfer, non-conventional driving forces, population balances Numerical methods to solve typical mechanistic models in chemical engineering including algebraic, ordinary and partial differential equations. Reactor and unsteady heat transfer modeling examples. Implementation of the models and numerical methods using Matlab/Simulink Homework assignment: Numeric Solving of differential equations; first principle modelling of process units
content.sv: Dynamical process modeling with material and energy balances Effect of rate models (mass and heat transfer, reaction rates) on modeling Specific topics in mass transfer: multicomponent mass transfer, non-conventional driving forces, population balances Numerical methods to solve typical mechanistic models in chemical engineering including algebraic, ordinary and partial differential equations. Reactor and unsteady heat transfer modeling examples. Implementation of the models and numerical methods using Matlab/Simulink Homework assignment: Numeric Solving of differential equations; first principle modelling of process units
content.en: Dynamical process modeling with material and energy balances Effect of rate models (mass and heat transfer, reaction rates) on modeling Specific topics in mass transfer: multicomponent mass transfer, non-conventional driving forces, population balances Numerical methods to solve typical mechanistic models in chemical engineering including algebraic, ordinary and partial differential equations. Reactor and unsteady heat transfer modeling examples. Implementation of the models and numerical methods using Matlab/Simulink Homework assignment: Numeric Solving of differential equations; first principle modelling of process units

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Basics of chemical reaction engineering, e.g. CHEM-C2130 or correponding knowledge
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: Basics of chemical reaction engineering, e.g. CHEM-C2130 or correponding knowledge
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Basics of chemical reaction engineering, e.g. CHEM-C2130 or correponding knowledge

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student
  1. knows the principles of heterogeneous catalysis
  2. recognizes the steps (diffusion, adsorption/desorption, surface reaction) in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  3. knows the types of homogeneous catalysis and is able to derive rate equations of acid/base catalyzed homogeneous reactions
  4. can derive rate equations based on steps of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  5. knows the different forms of deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts and can derive rate of deactivation based on the type  of deactivation
  6. is able to evaluate existence of diffusion limitations in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  7. can use methods applied for the evaluation of internal and external diffusion limitations in heterogeneous catalysis
  8. can combine the rate equations of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions to reactor mass balance equations and use these equations for the reactor design
  9. knows the principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts in the packed catalyst beds

content.fi:
1. Fundamentals and steps of heterogeneous catalysis
  2. Reaction mechanisms and rate equations of heterogeneously catalysed reactions
  3. Reaction mechanisms and rate equations of homogeneously catalysed reactions
  4. Deactivation mechanisms and rates in heterogeous catalysis
  5. Internal and external mass transfer in heterogenous catalysis
  6. Coupling of reactor mass balances (pseudohomogeneous model) and rate equations of catalysed reactions
  7. The principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts and the mechanical reliability of the packed catalyst beds

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: Basics of chemical reaction engineering, e.g. CHEM-C2130 or correponding knowledge
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: Basics of chemical reaction engineering, e.g. CHEM-C2130 or correponding knowledge
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Basics of chemical reaction engineering, e.g. CHEM-C2130 or correponding knowledge

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student
  1. knows the principles of heterogeneous catalysis
  2. recognizes the steps (diffusion, adsorption/desorption, surface reaction) in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  3. knows the types of homogeneous catalysis and is able to derive rate equations of acid/base catalyzed homogeneous reactions
  4. can derive rate equations based on steps of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  5. knows the different forms of deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts and can derive rate of deactivation based on the type  of deactivation
  6. is able to evaluate existence of diffusion limitations in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  7. can use methods applied for the evaluation of internal and external diffusion limitations in heterogeneous catalysis
  8. can combine the rate equations of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions to reactor mass balance equations and use these equations for the reactor design
  9. knows the principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts in the packed catalyst beds

  4. can derive rate equations based on steps of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  5. knows the different forms of deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts and can derive rate of deactivation based on the type  of deactivation
  6. is able to evaluate existence of diffusion limitations in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions
  7. can use methods applied for the evaluation of internal and external diffusion limitations in heterogeneous catalysis
  8. can combine the rate equations of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions to reactor mass balance equations and use these equations for the reactor design
  9. knows the principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts in the packed catalyst beds

  4. can derive rate equations based on steps of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions

  6. is able to evaluate existence of diffusion limitations in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions

content.fi:
1. Fundamentals and steps of heterogeneous catalysis
  2. Reaction mechanisms and rate equations of heterogeneously catalysed reactions
  3. Reaction mechanisms and rate equations of homogeneously catalysed reactions
  4. Deactivation mechanisms and rates in heterogeous catalysis
  5. Internal and external mass transfer in heterogenous catalysis
  6. Coupling of reactor mass balances (pseudohomogeneous model) and rate equations of catalysed reactions
  7. The principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts and the mechanical reliability of the packed catalyst beds

  5. Internal and external mass transfer in heterogenous catalysis
  6. Coupling of reactor mass balances (pseudohomogeneous model) and rate equations of catalysed reactions
  7. The principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts and the mechanical reliability of the packed catalyst beds
content.en:
1. Fundamentals and steps of heterogeneous catalysis

  3. Reaction mechanisms and rate equations of homogeneously catalysed reactions
  4. Deactivation mechanisms and rates in heterogeous catalysis
  5. Internal and external mass transfer in heterogenous catalysis
  6. Coupling of reactor mass balances (pseudohomogeneous model) and rate equations of catalysed reactions
  7. The principles of the mechanical strength of solid catalysts and the mechanical reliability of the packed catalyst beds

prerequisites.fi: CHEM-E7150 Reaction Engineering
prerequisites.sv: CHEM-E7150 Reaction Engineering
prerequisites.en: CHEM-E7150 Reaction Engineering

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student is able to
  1. describe different phenomena (e.g. reactions and mass  transfer) in industrial reactors
  2. combine rate equations and stoichiometry with balance equations of multiphase reactors
  3. apply mass and energy balances for different industrial multiphase reactors and perform calculations using the  balances
  4. explain the principles of computational calculations of multiphase reactors
  5. recognizes the applications of different  industrial reactor types
  6. plan a reactor concept for a given industrially relevant reaction system, including selection and use of   the simulation model as well as preliminary dimensioning of an industrial reactor
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course the student is able to
  1. describe different phenomena (e.g. reactions and mass  transfer) in industrial reactors
  2. combine rate equations and stoichiometry with balance equations of multiphase reactors
  3. apply mass and energy balances for different industrial multiphase reactors and perform calculations using the  balances
  4. explain the principles of computational calculations of multiphase reactors
  5. recognizes the applications of different  industrial reactor types
  6. plan a reactor concept for a given industrially relevant reaction system, including selection and use of   the simulation model as well as preliminary dimensioning of an industrial reactor
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student is able to

  2. combine rate equations and stoichiometry with balance equations of multiphase reactors
  3. apply mass and energy balances for different industrial multiphase reactors and perform calculations using the  balances
  4. explain the principles of computational calculations of multiphase reactors
  5. recognizes the applications of different  industrial reactor types
  6. plan a reactor concept for a given industrially relevant reaction system, including selection and use of   the simulation model as well as preliminary dimensioning of an industrial reactor

content.fi:
Must know:
  • theories and phenomena behind the mass and energy balances as well as mass transfer in multiphase  reactors
  • principles of combining rate equations, balance equations and stoichiometry
  • basic principles of computational calculations of multiphase reactors
  • how to select the reactor type for a given chemical system
Should know:
  • how to implement the reactor mass and energy balances in given simulation software
  • how to choose the numerical solving strategies for the given reactor model
  • how to carry out the preliminary dimensioning for given chemical system using computational calculations
Nice to know:
  • ways to intensify chemical reactors
  • main industrial applications of different reactor types
  • derivation of mass and energy balance equations from basic theories

workload.fi: 5 op = 135 h Tutustuminen tutkimusryhmään ja tutkimuksen tavoitteisiin 30 h Mittaukset/tutkimusprojektin toteuttaminen 80 h Raportointi 20 h Loppuseminaari 5 h
workload.sv:
5 sp= 135 h
Inblick i forskningsgrupp och forskningens mål 30h
Mätning/genomförande av projekt 80h
Rapportering 20h
Seminarium 5h
workload.en: 5 cr= 135 h, getting to know the research team and the goals of the research 30h, measurements/carrying out the research project 80h, reporting 20h, final seminar 5h

learningOutcomes.fi: Projektityön tavoitteena on tutustuttaa opiskelija tutkimusryhmän työhön.
learningOutcomes.sv: Syftet med projektarbetet är att studerande blir bekant med forskningsgruppens arbete.
learningOutcomes.en: The goal of the project work is to familiarize the student with the work of a research team.

content.fi: Projektityössä opiskelija tutustuu projektin tavoitteisiin ja osallistuu tutkimusprojektin toteuttamiseen osallistumalla tutkimusryhmän työskentelyyn itsenäisesti ryhmän jäsenenä. Opiskelija raportoi tulokset sovitulla tavalla kirjallisesti sekä esittää ne suullisesti.
content.sv: Under projektarbetet blir studeranden bekant med syftet av projektet och deltar i forskningsprojektet genom att arbeta självständigt i gruppen. Studerande rapporterar sina resultat både skriftlig och muntlig.
content.en: In the project the student will learn of the goals of the project and take part in carrying out the project by working in the research group as an independent member. The student will then prepare a written report of the results in a pre-defined manner and also orally present them.

assesmentMethods.fi: Itsenäinen projektityö ja sen raportointi.
assesmentMethods.sv: Självständigt projektarbete och rapportering.
assesmentMethods.en: Independent project work and reporting.

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: The laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.Recommended prerequisites: CHEM-E6160 Fundamentals of Pyrometallurgy
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: The laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.Recommended prerequisites: CHEM-E6160 Fundamentals of Pyrometallurgy
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: The laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.Recommended prerequisites: CHEM-E6160 Fundamentals of Pyrometallurgy

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student can
- describe the fundamental sub-processes in the oxidation and reduction processes, their driving forces and constraints, including transport phenomena.
- understand the features of heterogeneous reactions at elevated temperatures, such as slag-matte-metal-gas systems, surface phenomena and fundamentals of fluxing.
- is able to explain the principles of essential pyrometallurgical laboratory techniques and understand the role of experimental work on process development.
- can design and conduct experiments for studying different phenomena at elevated temperatures.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course the student can
- describe the fundamental sub-processes in the oxidation and reduction processes, their driving forces and constraints, including transport phenomena.
- understand the features of heterogeneous reactions at elevated temperatures, such as slag-matte-metal-gas systems, surface phenomena and fundamentals of fluxing.
- is able to explain the principles of essential pyrometallurgical laboratory techniques and understand the role of experimental work on process development.
- can design and conduct experiments for studying different phenomena at elevated temperatures.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student can
- describe the fundamental sub-processes in the oxidation and reduction processes, their driving forces and constraints, including transport phenomena.
- understand the features of heterogeneous reactions at elevated temperatures, such as slag-matte-metal-gas systems, surface phenomena and fundamentals of fluxing.
- is able to explain the principles of essential pyrometallurgical laboratory techniques and understand the role of experimental work on process development.
- can design and conduct experiments for studying different phenomena at elevated temperatures.

content.fi: This course goes deeper into metals production processes concentrating on chemical and physical phenomena in the unit process level - the main processes and constraints taking place in the metallurgical operations at elevated temperatures are considered. The emphasis is on oxidation and reduction processes, as well as on surface phenomena and multiphase phenomena (e.g. melting/dissolution, reaction, transport and solidification phenomena) in slag-metal gas-solid systems. In addition some experimental research techniques for studying phenomena at elevated temperatures are introduced and experiments as well as data analysis will be carried out.

workload.fi: The course contains lectures, assignments, self-study, and final exam.
workload.sv: The course contains lectures, assignments, self-study, and final exam.

prerequisites.fi: Recommended prerequisites: The course presupposes basic knowledge and competences in the field of Biosciences, which are in content, scope and quality similar to those offered in the following Aalto bachelor-level courses - CHEM-A1310 Basics in Bioscience or CHEM-C1300 Fundamental Biosciences AND - CHEM-C2300 Cell and Molecular Biology AND - CHEM-C2330 Biochemistry
prerequisites.sv: Recommended prerequisites: The course presupposes basic knowledge and competences in the field of Biosciences, which are in content, scope and quality similar to those offered in the following Aalto bachelor-level courses - CHEM-A1310 Basics in Bioscience or CHEM-C1300 Fundamental Biosciences AND - CHEM-C2300 Cell and Molecular Biology AND - CHEM-C2330 Biochemistry
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: The course presupposes basic knowledge and competences in the field of Biosciences, which are in content, scope and quality similar to those offered in the following Aalto bachelor-level courses - CHEM-A1310 Basics in Bioscience or CHEM-C1300 Fundamental Biosciences AND - CHEM-C2300 Cell and Molecular Biology AND - CHEM-C2330 Biochemistry

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the students will be able to:
  • Appreciate the molecular basis of biological organization and cells
  • Understand the biological processes critical for cellular functioning
  • Can integrate the different processes into the proper cellular context
  • Asses the function of regulatory pathways and networks at the cellular level
  • Describe the general principles of gene organization and expression
  • Critically analyze experimental data

  • Asses the function of regulatory pathways and networks at the cellular level
  • Describe the general principles of gene organization and expression
  • Critically analyze experimental data
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the students will be able to:
  • Appreciate the molecular basis of biological organization and cells
  • Understand the biological processes critical for cellular functioning
  • Can integrate the different processes into the proper cellular context
  • Asses the function of regulatory pathways and networks at the cellular level
  • Describe the general principles of gene organization and expression
  • Critically analyze experimental data

content.fi: The course aims at providing the understanding of essential cellular processes (DNA replication, gene expression, protein targeting and transport, the processing of proteins, membrane transport, secretion and endocytosis, cell signaling, and the regulation of cell death and cell cycle). The course focuses on eukaryotic organisms.

After the course the students will be able to:
  • Appreciate the molecular basis of biological organization and cells
  • Understand the biological processes critical for cellular functioning
  • Can integrate the different processes into the proper cellular context
  • Asses the function of regulatory pathways and networks at the cellular level
  • Describe the general principles of gene organization and expression
  • Critically analyze experimental data
learningOutcomes.en:

  • Understand the biological processes critical for cellular functioning
  • Can integrate the different processes into the proper cellular context
  • Asses the function of regulatory pathways and networks at the cellular level
  • Describe the general principles of gene organization and expression
  • Critically analyze experimental data

content.fi: The course aims at providing the understanding of essential cellular processes (DNA replication, gene expression, protein targeting and transport, the processing of proteins, membrane transport, secretion and endocytosis, cell signaling, and the regulation of cell death and cell cycle). The course focuses on eukaryotic organisms.

learningOutcomes.fi:
• understand what differentiates scientific articles from other publications such as web pages, 
  • are able to recognize typical parts of scientific articles that report original research (IMRaD) and find the conclusion of an article, 
  • know how to formulate citation, in a given format
    (we practice the format of Aalto CHEM instructions), 
  • are able to describe how the impact of a scientific journal and of an individual article is (attempted to be) assessed, 
  • have practiced formulating his/her own view (/comment/opinion) on a scientific article, 
  • be able to use a similarity detection software, 
  • have made peer evaluation.

content.fi: This course introduces the student to the field of scientific publishing: what is a scientific article and how it differs from a web page, what is peer review, how to find scientific journals and how is the quality of various scientific publishing forums attempted to be assessed. As part of the course, the student will do an exercise, where the student finds a unique peer-reviewed scientific article reporting original research, makes a structured analysis of it, uses a similarity detection software, and gives and gets peer feedback.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student, can summarize the steps in producing chemical pulp in laboratory, the emphasis being in kraft pulping,
has practiced the most essential experimental and analytical methods in the area of biomass refining and can also describe some less conventional practical laboratory methods,
has experience in systematic project planning and in team working,
has practiced giving and receiving personal feedback on work performance,
is able to present findings in written and oral format.

content.fi: Student teams plan and execute a fractionation scheme for (wood) biomass, aiming at understanding it from ra material, process and product perspective. The laboratory work includes preparation, pulping, bleaching, and characterizing the biomass raw material and products. The student team reports the project in a written report and presents the work in a seminar.

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-E2225 Wood Material ScienceThe laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-E2235: Wood Materials ScienceThe laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-E2235: Wood Materials ScienceThe laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course the student:
  • knows how to identify wood species from their macroscopic (visible with 'naked eye' or hand lens) and microscopic structures (optical microscope using biological slides), and infer properties from these characteristics
  • is able to determine the density of wood
  • is able to determine the moisture content of wood and assess the accuracy of different methods of measurement 
  • is familiar with measuring short-term mechanical properties of wood and wood-based composites and assess the effects of anisotropy and moisture content on these.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course the student:
  • knows how to identify wood species from their macroscopic (visible with 'naked eye' or hand lens) and microscopic structures (optical microscope using biological slides), and infer properties from these characteristics
  • is able to determine the density of wood
  • is able to determine the moisture content of wood and the assess the accuracy of different methods of measurement 
  • is familiar with measuring short-term mechanical properties of wood and wood-based composites and assess the effects of anisotropy and moisture content on these.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student:
  • knows how to identify wood species from their macroscopic (visible with 'naked eye' or hand lens) and microscopic structures (optical microscope using biological slides), and infer properties from these characteristics
  • is able to determine the density of wood
  • is able to determine the moisture content of wood and the assess the accuracy of different methods of measurement 
  • is familiar with measuring short-term mechanical properties of wood and wood-based composites and assess the effects of anisotropy and moisture content on these.

content.fi:
The course complements the theoretical understanding about wood gained in CHEM-E2225 Wood Material Science by introducing students to practical experimental work related to wood and wood products. The course is primarily laboratory-based, with some lectures. The content covers:
  • Macroscopic and microscopic examination of wood's anatomical features 
  • Determination of selected physical properties, including moisture content and density
  • Measurement of the mechanical properties of wood and wood-based composites
content.sv:

  • Determination of selected physical properties, including moisture content and density
  • Measurement of the mechanical properteis of wood and wood-based composites

learningOutcomes.fi: After the course student has an overall picture of Natural fiber-based packaging: - structure of paper and board - main characteristics of board-based packaging (including converted products) - main raw materials - main production process characteristics - key functional properties of the end-products and their connection to the raw material quality - current sustainability trends in the field of natural fiber-based packaging
learningOutcomes.sv: After the course student has an overall picture of Natural fiber-based packaging: - structure of paper and board - main characteristics of board-based packaging (including converted products) - main raw materials - main production process characteristics - key functional properties of the end-products and their connection to the raw material quality - current sustainability trends in the field of natural fiber-based packaging
learningOutcomes.en: After the course student has an overall picture of Natural fiber-based packaging: - structure of paper and board - main characteristics of board-based packaging (including converted products) - main raw materials - main production process characteristics - key functional properties of the end-products and their connection to the raw material quality - current sustainability trends in the field of natural fiber-based packaging

content.fi:
Main functional properties of paper and board
Natural fibre raw materials (chemical pulp, mechanical pulp, recycled pulp, polyethylene) of paper and board making and connection to the functional properties of paper+board+converted products
Main unit operations in paper and board making and converting: process efficiency, role of pulp quality, effects to the end product properties
Current topics in sustainability e.g. recycling and biopolymers in fibre-based packaging

learningOutcomes.fi:
Course ILOs:
 
After attending the module, the students
- are familiar with the MATLAB and Python environments and can perform basic operations, such as simple programming, importing data and plotting graphics
- are able to create and combine variables (scalars, vectors, matrices)
- are familiar with basic numerical methods, such as numerical differentiation and integration integrals, approximate derivatives, and solving linear systems
- can use MATLAB and Python solver(s) for solving differential equations

content.fi: This is the Basic course for learning MATLAB and Python. The usual pattern of teaching/learning MATLAB and Python has been changed from a programming view point to a mathematical one. The idea is that by thinking about mathematical problems, students are prodded into learning MATLAB and Python for the purpose of solving the problem at hand.

prerequisites.fi: Pakolliset esitiedot: CHEM-A1200 Kemiallinen rakenne ja sitoutuminen TAI CHEM-A1270 Yleinen kemia JA CHEM-A1280 Kemian peruslaboratoriotyöt. Laboratorioturvallisuuskurssi CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 tai CHEM-E0140 on oltava suoritettuna ennen laboratoriotöiden aloittamista.Suositellut esitiedot: CHEM-C2215 Epäorgaaninen kemia -kurssin suorittamista ennen tätä kurssia suositellaan.
prerequisites.sv: Obligatoriska förkunskaper: CHEM-A1200 Kemisk struktur och bindning ELLER CHEM-A1270 Allmän kemi OCH CHEM-A1280 Grundläggande laboratoriearbeten i kemi. För deltagande i laborationerna krävs godkänd kurs i laborationssäkerhet: CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 eller CHEM-E0140.Rekommenderade förkunskaper: Avläggandet av kursen CHEM-C2215 Oorganisk kemi rekommenderas innan denna kurs.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-A1200 Chemical Structure and Bonding OR CHEM-A1270 General Chemistry AND CHEM-A1280 Basic Laboratory Work in Chemistry. The laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.Recommended prerequisites: Completion of CHEM-C2215 Inorganic Chemistry course prior to this course is recommended.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin suoritettuaan opiskelija osaa:
  • toteuttaa erilaisia epäorgaanisia synteesejä
  • karakterisoida tuotteita eri menetelmillä
  • tulkita analyysituloksia ja raportoida tuloksia
learningOutcomes.sv:
Efter godkänd kurs ska studenten kunna:
  • göra olika oorganiska synteser
  • karakterisera syntesprodukter med olika metoder
  • tolka analysresultat och rapportera resultat
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student will be able to:
  • do different kinds of inorganic synthesis
  • characterize products with different methods
  • interpret the analysis results and make reports

content.fi:

  • de vanligaste karakteriseringsmetoderna för oorganiska material
content.en:
• synthesis of inorganic materials
  • the general characterization methods of inorganic materials

Consequently, all the compulsory prerequisites for "Functional Soft Materials D" course. The laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.Recommended prerequisites: Fundamental knowledge in polymer chemistry and physics.

learningOutcomes.fi:
When participating in the course the student will be able to develop the following knowledge and skills: 
- Ability to work in a group on an open-ended soft materials development challenge and to name and apply basic tools for research project management.
- Ability to search and identify relevant scientific literature to the challenge and make informed executive decisions based on that.
- Develop expertise and capabilities in time management of a short-term project.
- Develop knowledge and expertise in research methods, processes and techniques employed in soft materials science and applications.
- Develop knowledge and expertise in presentation and pitching skills. - Develop knowledge and expertise in understanding the boundary conditions and constrains in materials design, for instance related to sustainability.
- Develop knowledge of the professional role of innovation, R&D, or product development manager as a career path option.

prerequisites.fi: Suositellut esitiedot: Perus- ja aineopinnot kemiasta.
prerequisites.sv: Rekommenderade förkunskaper: Grund- och ämnesstudier i kemi.
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: Basic and intermediate studies in BSc level chemistry.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurrssin suoritettuaan opiskelija
  • Osaa kuvata molekyylien rakennetta kvanttimekaanisin mallein.
  • Osaa hyödyntää kvanttimekaanisia malleja päättelyn työkaluina ongelmanratkaisussa.
  • Osaa piirtää moniatomisille molekyyleille molekyyliorbitaalidiagrammeja.
  • Osa tulkita molekyyliorbitaalipiirroksia sekä molekyyliorbitaalidiagrammeja.
learningOutcomes.sv:
Efter kurssen en kan studenten
  • representera molekylstrukturer med hjläp av kvantmekaniska modeller.
  • använda kvantmekaniska modeller i problemlösning.
  • rita molekylorbitaler för polyatomära molekyler.
  • tolka molekylorbitalritningar och molekylorbitaldiagrammer.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student will be able to
  • represent molecules using quantum mechanical models.
  • utilize quantum mechanical models in solving chemical problems.
  • draw molecular orbital diagrams for polyatomic molecules.
  • interpret molecular orbital drawings and molecular orbital diagrams.

content.fi:
• Molekyylien esitystavat.
  • Stereokemia.
  • Atomiorbitaalit, kemiallinen sitoutuminen.
  • Molekyyliorbitaalit, valenssisidosorbitaalit, kanoniset orbitaalit.
  • Kemiallisen reaktion kuvaaminen kvanttimekaanisesti.
content.sv:
• Olika molekylära representationer.
  • Stereokemi.
  • Atomära orbitaler, kemisk binding.
  • Molekulära orbitaler, valensbindingsorbitaler, kanoniska orbitaler.
  • Kvantmekanisk syn på kemiska reaktioner.
content.en:
• Molecular representations.
  • Stereochemistry.
  • Atomic orbitals, chemical bonding.
  • Molecular orbitals, valence bond orbitals, canonical orbitals.
  • Quantum mechanical view of a chemical reaction.

assesmentMethods.fi: Kolme (3) arvosteltavaa kotitehtävää.
assesmentMethods.sv: Tre (3) graderade hemmupgifter.
assesmentMethods.en: Three (3) graded homework problems.

name.en: Laboratory Work in Surface Chemistry, Lecture

workload.fi:
2 op = 54 t
Laboratorytyöt, laboratoriotulosten raportointi.
workload.sv:
2 sp = 54 t
Laborationer, rapportering av laboratorieresultat.
workload.en:
2 cr = 54 h
Laboratory works, reporting of laboratory results.

prerequisites.fi: Pakolliset esitiedot: CHEM-A1280 Kemian peruslaboratoriotyötSuositellut esitiedot: On erittäin suositeltavaa, että opiskelijat suorittavat kurssin CHEM-C2230 Pintakemia ja tämän laboratoriokurssin saman kevätlukukauden aikana.
prerequisites.sv: Obligatoriska förkunskaper: CHEM-A1280 Grundläggande laboratoriearbeten i kemiRekommenderade förkunskaper: Det rekommenderas starkt att studenterna genomför CHEM-C2230 Ytkemi och denna laborationskurs under samma vårtermin.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-A1280 Basic Laboratory Work in ChemistryRecommended prerequisites: It is strongly recommended that students take the course CHEM-C2230 Surface Chemistry and this laboratory course during the same spring semester.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Tällä kurssilla opiskelijat:
  • Kehittävät kokeellisia laboratoriotaitojaan.
  • Ymmärtävät kokeellisten töiden avulla syvällisemmin joitain rajapinta-ilmiöitä.
  • Soveltavat pintakemian teoreettisia käsitteitä käytännössä.
learningOutcomes.sv:
I denna kurs kommer de studerande att:
  • Utveckla sina praktiska färdigheter när de arbetar i laboratoriet.
  • Förstå djupare vissa gränssnittsfenomen genom att utföra praktiska experiment.
  • Tillämpa teoretiska ytkemibegrepp i praktiken.
learningOutcomes.en:
In this course the students will:
  • Develop their hands-on skills working in the laboratory.
  • Understand more deeply some interfacial phenomena through experimentation.
  • Apply theoretical concepts from surface chemistry to practical cases.

content.fi: Tämä on laboratoriokurssi, joka täydentää kurssia CHEM-C2230 Pintakemia. Opiskelija osaa soveltaa kurssin teoreettista tietämystä pintakemiaan liittyvien tiettyjen ilmiöiden analysoimiseen erilaisissa laboratoriotöissä.
content.sv: Detta är en labbkurs som kompletterar kursen CHEM-C2230 Ytkemi. Den studerande kan tillämpa en del av den teoretiska kunskapen från ytkemikursen för att analysera vissa fenomen relaterade till ytkemi i olika laboratoriearbeten.
content.en: This is a lab course that complements the course CHEM-C2230 Surface Chemistry. The students can apply some of the theoretical knowledge from that course to analyse specific phenomena related to surface chemistry in different laboratory works.

workload.fi: Lectures, group work, presemo and practical exercises

prerequisites.fi: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-E1170 Introduction to Sustainability in the Bioeconomy or similar course such as CHEM-E1220 Sustainability in the Bioproducts Industry.
prerequisites.sv: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-E1170 Introduction to Sustainability in the Bioeconomy or similar course such as CHEM-E1220 Sustainability in the Bioproducts Industry.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-E1170 Introduction to Sustainability in the Bioeconomy or similar course such as CHEM-E1220 Sustainability in the Bioproducts Industry.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course, the students can​
  • Apply a systems thinking approach to evaluate bioproduct production processes using sustainability lenses. ​
  • Gain hands-on experience with sustainability assessment methods and tools.
  • Work in groups to identify and propose solutions to complex issues to de-risk and identify the most sustainable path for bringing lab-scale processes into reality.
  • Improve research, collaboration, data processing, interpretation and presentation skills.
  • Critically analyze bioproducts from a technical, economic, social and environmental perspective, proposing a sustainability value proposition.
learningOutcomes.sv:
After the course, the students can​
  • Apply a systems thinking approach to evaluate bioproduct production processes using sustainability lenses. ​
  • Gain hands-on experience with sustainability assessment methods and tools.
  • Work in groups to identify and propose solutions to complex issues to de-risk and identify the most sustainable path for bringing lab-scale processes into reality.
  • Improve research, collaboration, data processing, interpretation and presentation skills.
  • Critically analyze bioproducts from a technical, economic, social and environmental perspective, proposing a sustainability value proposition.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course, the students can​
  • Apply a systems thinking approach to evaluate bioproduct production processes using sustainability lenses. ​
  • Gain hands-on experience with sustainability assessment methods and tools.
  • Work in groups to identify and propose solutions to complex issues to de-risk and identify the most sustainable path for bringing lab-scale processes into reality.
  • Improve research, collaboration, data processing, interpretation and presentation skills.
  • Critically analyze bioproducts from a technical, economic, social and environmental perspective, proposing a sustainability value proposition.

content.fi: Preliminary course descriptionThis course focuses on applying tools and methods learned in the Introduction to Sustainability in the Bioeconomy course. It adds a practical perspective via the sustainability assessment of pre-defined case studies.In groups, the students will assess case studies based on biomaterials/bioproducts developed by Bio2 research groups and/or industry.Lectures will be given at the beginning of the course to (1) remind the students of the tools and methods applied, (2) describe the project subject and scope, (3) form the teams and book tutoring sections, etc.The groups will work closely with the specialisation/package responsible for gathering additional information to assess case studies.The evaluation is a presentation and a one-pager critical analysis of the sustainability profile, solution value proposition, risks identified, and solutions proposed.

It adds a practical perspective via the sustainability assessment of pre-defined case studies.In groups, the students will assess case studies based on biomaterials/bioproducts developed by Bio2 research groups and/or industry.Lectures will be given at the beginning of the course to (1) remind the students of the tools and methods applied, (2) describe the project subject and scope, (3) form the teams and book tutoring sections, etc.The groups will work closely with the specialisation/package responsible for gathering additional information to assess case studies.The evaluation is a presentation and a one-pager critical analysis of the sustainability profile, solution value proposition, risks identified, and solutions proposed.
content.en: Preliminary course descriptionThis course focuses on applying tools and methods learned in the Introduction to Sustainability in the Bioeconomy course. It adds a practical perspective via the sustainability assessment of pre-defined case studies.In groups, the students will assess case studies based on biomaterials/bioproducts developed by Bio2 research groups and/or industry.Lectures will be given at the beginning of the course to (1) remind the students of the tools and methods applied, (2) describe the project subject and scope, (3) form the teams and book tutoring sections, etc.The groups will work closely with the specialisation/package responsible for gathering additional information to assess case studies.The evaluation is a presentation and a one-pager critical analysis of the sustainability profile, solution value proposition, risks identified, and solutions proposed.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course, the student:
  • is familiar with the degree structure and contents of the Chemistry and Materials Science MSc programme.
  • is familiar with the student services and wellbeing services at Aalto University.
  • is able to plan their MSc studies and update the study plan as necessary.
  • is able to give constructive feedback related to studies and study environment.
  • knows the MSc thesis process in the programme and is aware of the possibilities for finding a topic for the MSc thesis.
  • has an understanding of the industrial and academic career possibilities in chemistry and materials science.
  • knows what kind of possibilities there are for doctoral studies at the Aalto School of Chemical Engineering.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After the course, the student will be able to:
  • Choose a correct analytical technique for investigating a certain property in a bio-based sample
  • Possess hands-on skills in sample preparation, measuring and interpreting the data for physical and chemical characteristics of bio-based samples
  • Understand the hierarchical morphology of plant fibres from analytical point of view
  • Master the multiple length scales in biomass from atomic scale to macroscopic objects
  • Apply the principles of spectroscopy, scattering, chromatography, microscopy and mechanical characterization into bio-based materials

name.en: Professional Development as a Chemical Engineer, Lecture

workload.fi:

Kurssin suorittaminen edellyttää osallistumista luennoille.
workload.sv:
Kontaktundervisning, uppgifter, grupparbete
Kursen förutsätter att den studerande deltar i kontaktundervisningen
workload.en:
Contact teaching, assignments, group work
To pass the course, student needs to attend the contact sessions

prerequisites.fi: Suositellut esitiedot: 45 op kemian tekniikan kandidaatin opintoja TAI kemian tekniikan korkeakoulun maisteriohjelman opinto-oikeus
prerequisites.sv: Rekommenderade förkunskaper: 45 sp studier på kandidatnivå i kemiteknik ELLER studierätt i ett magisterprogramm i högskolan för kemiteknik
prerequisites.en: Recommended prerequisites: 45 cr. of studies at Bachelor's level in Chemical Engineering (Finnish BSc) OR study right in a master's programme at the School of Chemical Engineering

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin jälkeen opiskelija osaa
  • jäsentää omaa osaamistaan, omia vahvuuksiaan sekä oman ammatti-identiteettinsä rakentumisen polkua
  • analysoida, millaiset tekijät ovat keskeisiä oman jaksamisen ja hyvinvoinnin kannalta ehkäisten uupumista
  • kuvata, mitkä ulkoiset ja sisäiset tekijät edistävät motivoitumista omissa opinnoissa ja työssä
  • arvioida omia geneerisiä työelämätaitojaan ja soveltaa tilanteeseen soveltuvia työskentelytapoja 
  • hahmottaa proaktiivisesti muuttuvan työelämän ja muuttuvan maailman vaikutuksia sekä työelämävaatimuksiin että -mahdollisuuksiin
learningOutcomes.sv:
Efter kursen
  • vet studenten hur man strukturerar sin kompetens, styrkor och sättet att bygga sin egen yrkesidentitet
  • kan studenten analysera vilka faktorer som är centrala när det gäller personlig välmående och därigenom förebygga utbrändhet
  • kan studenten förklara vilka yttre och inre faktorer som främjar motivation i sina egna studierna och i sitt eget arbete
  • kan studenten utvärdera sin egen generiska arbetslivskompetens och tillämpa arbetsmetoder lämpliga för situationen
  • kan studenten proaktivt uppfatta effekterna av ett föränderligt arbetsliv och en föränderlig värld på både arbetslivets krav och möjligheter
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course, the student
  • analyze their own skills, strengths and the path to building their own professional identity
  • can analyze which factors are central to personal thriving and well-being in order to prevent burnout
  • can describe which external and internal factors promote motivation in their own studies and work
  • can evaluate their generic work-life skills and apply way of working suitable to the situation
  • can proactively observe the demands and opportunities of the changing working life and the world

content.fi:
Kurssin tavoitteena on opetella taitoja ja työtapoja, jotka edistävät hyvinvoivaksi, tulevaisuuden työelämässä pärjääväksi insinööriksi kehittymistä:
  • Hyvinvointitaidot: epävarmuuden sieto, stressinhallinta/resilienssi, tunteiden säätely
  • Ammatti-identiteettitaidot: oman insinööri-identiteetin rakentaminen muuttuvassa maailmassa, oman osaamisen ja vahvuuksien tunnistaminen sekä jäsentäminen koherentiksi kokonaisuudeksi
  • Työskentely- ja projektinhallintataidot: rakentavan palautteen vastaanottaminen ja antaminen, ajankäytön suunnittelu, tiimityötaidot, omien työskentelytapojen arviointi sekä vastuunotto omasta opiskelusta.
content.sv:
Målet med kursen är att lära sig färdigheter och arbetssätt som främjar utvecklingen av en framgångsrik kemiingenjörsexpert som kan klara sig i framtidens arbetsliv
  • Välbefinnande färdigheter: osäkerhetstolerans, stresshantering/resiliens, känsloreglering
  • Professionella identitetsfärdigheter: bygga din egen identitet som ingenjör i en föränderlig värld, identifiera dina egna färdigheter och styrkor och strukturera dem till en sammanhängande helhet
  • Arbets- och projektledningsförmåga: ta emot och ge konstruktiv feedback, tidsplanering, lagarbete, utvärdering av egna arbetsvanor och engagemang för studier
content.en:
The goal of the course is to learn skills and working methods that promote the well-being and the development of a chemical engineering expert to succeed in the future working life
  • Well-being skills: uncertainty tolerance, stress management/resilience, emotion regulation
  • Professional identity skills: building your own identity as an engineer in a changing world, identifying your own skills and strengths and structuring them into a coherent whole
  • Work and project management skills: receiving and giving constructive feedback, planning the use of time, teamwork skills, evaluating one's own work habits and committing to one's own studies

name.en: Basic Laboratory Work in Chemistry, Lecture

workload.fi:
54 h = 2 op
Kontaktiopetus (luennot, laboratoriotyöt, laskutupa), virtuaalilaboratorio, laboratoriotulosten raportointi, kotitehtävät, itsenäinen opiskelu.
workload.sv:
54 h = 2 sp
Kontaktundervisning (föreläsningar, laborationer, räknestuga), virtuellt laboratorium, rapportering av laboratorieresultat, hemuppgifter, självständiga studier.
workload.en:
54 h = 2 cr
Contact teaching (lectures, laboratory works, calculus exercise), virtual laboratory, reporting of laboratory results, homework, independent studying.

prerequisites.fi: Pakolliset esitiedot: Laboratorioturvallisuuskurssi CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 tai CHEM-E0140 on oltava suoritettuna ennen laboratoriotöiden aloittamista.
prerequisites.sv: Obligatoriska förkunskaper: För deltagande i laborationerna krävs godkänd kurs i laborationssäkerhet: CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 eller CHEM-E0140.
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: The laboratory safety course CHEM-A1030, CHEM-E0111, CHEM-A1010 or CHEM-E0140 must be completed before starting laboratory work.

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin suoritettuaan, opiskelija osaa:
  1. työskennellä turvallisesti laboratoriossa
  2. tehdä havaintoja ja dokumentoida työtään
  3. analysoida tuloksia ja kirjoittaa raportteja
  4. työskennellä ryhmässä
  5. kuvata analyysimenetelmien (titrimetria, gravimetria, spektrofotometria, AAS) toimintaperiaatteet ja virhelähteet
learningOutcomes.sv:
Efter godkänd kurs ska studenten kunna:
  1. arbeta i laboratoriet på ett säkert sätt
  2. göra observationer och dokumentera sitt arbete
  3. analysera resultaten och skriva rapporter
  4. arbeta i grupp
  5. beskriva analysmetodernas (titrimetri, gravimetri, spektrofotometri, AAS) funktionsprinciper och felkällor.
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course, student will be able to
  1. work safely in a laboratory
  2. make observations and document his/hers work
  3. analyze results and write reports
  4. work in a group
  5. describe the principle of operation of analysis methods (titrimetry, gravimetry, spectrophotometry, AAS) and their sources of error.

content.fi:
Kemian laboratoriotöiden peruskurssi, jossa perehdytään seuraaviin:
  • Turvalliset työskentelytavat ja ryhmätyötaidot
  • Stoikiometria, reaktioyhtälö
  • Spektrofotometria, AAS, gravimetria, titrimetria
  • Laboratoriotulosten tulkinta, virhetarkastelu ja raportointi
content.sv:
Grundkurs i kemilaborationer, där följande ämnesområden behandlas:
  • Säkra arbetsmetoder och samarbetsförmåga
  • Stökiometri, reaktionsformler
  • Spektrofotometri, AAS, gravimetri, titrimetri
  • Tolkning, felanalys och rapportering av laboratorieresultat
content.en:
Basic course in chemistry laboratory work, where the following items are got acquainted with:
  • Safe working practices and groupwork skills
  • Stoichiometry, reaction equations
  • Spectrophotometry, AAS, gravimetry, titrimety
  • Interpretation, error analysis and reporting of laboratory results

assesmentMethods.sv: Föreläsningar, laborationer, rapporter, hemuppgifter.
assesmentMethods.en: Lectures, laboratory work, reports, homework.

prerequisites.fi: Pakolliset esitiedot: CHEM-A1230 tai vastaava orgaanisen kemian peruskurssiSuositellut esitiedot:
prerequisites.sv: Obligatoriska förkunskaper: CHEM-A1230 eller motsvarande grundkurs i organisk kemiRekommenderade förkunskaper:
prerequisites.en: Compulsory prerequisites: CHEM-A1230 or another basic course in organic chemistryRecommended prerequisites:

learningOutcomes.fi:
Kurssin suoritettuaan, opiskelija osaa :
  1. tunnistaa erilaiset reaktiotyypit (esim. additiot, eliminaatiot ja substituutiot)
  2. yleisimpien reaktiomekanismien perusteet
  3. suunnitella sekä toteuttaa orgaanisia synteesejä.
  4. karakterisoida tuotteita eri menetelmillä
  5. tulkita analyysituloksia ja raportoida tuloksia
learningOutcomes.sv:
Efter godkänd kurs bör studenten kunna :
  1. beskriva grundprincipen för hur reaktionsmekanismer skrivs
  2. förutspå enkla reaktioners mekanismer
  3. tillämpa denna kunskap för att bestämma struktur och stereokemi hos de produkter som bildas i olika synteser
learningOutcomes.en:
After the course the student will be able to :
  1. explain the basic idea of writing the reaction mechanism
  2. predict the mechanism of the reaction
  3. adapt the learned knowledge to the structure and stereochemistry of the product.

content.fi:
Kemian peruskurssi jossa perehdytään seuraaviin:
  • konformaatioanalyysin perusteet
  • elektrofiilinen additio alkeeneihin
  • elektrofiilinen aromaattinen substituutio
  • enolaatit
  • konjugaattiadditio
  • regioselektiivisyys
  • aldoli ja Claisen reaktiot
  • suojaryhmät
  • synteesisuunnittelu
  • heterosykliset yhdisteet
content.sv: Alkenernas reaktioner, konjugatadditioner, grundläggande information om kemo- och regioselektivitet, enolatkemi, grundläggande inromation om aromatiska föreningarnas kemi, Kunskap om molekyler vilka innehåller en heteroatom.
content.en: Electrophilic addition to alkenes, conjugate additions, chemo- and regioselectivity, enolate chemistry, elements of aromatic chemistry, heterocyclic compounds.

prerequisites.fi: CHEM-E2225 Wood material science 5 cr and CHEM-E2235 Wood products and processes 5 cr, or equivalent knowledge.
prerequisites.sv: CHEM-E2225 Wood material science 5 cr and CHEM-E2235 Wood products and processes 5 cr, or equivalent knowledge.
prerequisites.en: CHEM-E2225 Wood material science 5 cr and CHEM-E2235 Wood products and processes 5 cr, or equivalent knowledge.

learningOutcomes.fi:
After this course students:
  • are able to create a scientific research plan to investigate advanced material properties
  • are able to independently analyse results gained from advanced material analysing equipment, such as Raman microscopy or DVS
  • are able to report research results in the style and quality of peer-review journal manuscript
learningOutcomes.sv:
After this course students:
  • are able to create a scientific research plan to investigate advanced material properties
  • are able to independently analyse results gained from advanced material analysing equipment, such as Raman microscopy or DVS
  • are able to report research results in the style and quality of peer-review journal manuscript
learningOutcomes.en:
After this course students:
  • are able to create a scientific research plan to investigate advanced material properties
  • are able to independently analyse results gained from advanced material analysing equipment, such as Raman microscopy or DVS
  • are able to report research results in the style and quality of peer-review journal manuscript

content.fi: This course includes advanced analytical techniques to examine the material properties of wood and wood-based materials. Techniques can include e.g. numerical methods, DVS, FTIR, Raman microscopy, etc. Research topics can be related to e.g. wood physics and micromechanics, wood and water interaction or wood structure and property interaction. The materials investigated can be e.g. different wood species, wood-based composites or modified wood. The results are reported in compact form (e.g. a manuscript for peer-review journal).
